comments.commentBody: Get real.  Initial money may come from the US, but after that virtually all foreign investment by US firms is generated overseas.  Check the data, and check your emotions.  It is less expensive for the firms to borrow abroad or to self-finance abroad than it is to bring the money back to the US and pay stiff US corporate income tax; also, are you aware US is number one debtor nation...not creditor.

No offense, but what part of exports do you not understand?

Not to mention that the expertise tends to stay in the US due to better opportunities and work environment, and the knowledge is free on the Internet. The article makes a case why the jobs will come back, and if you've been checking the news regarding tech support you'd know that it's already starting.

Ross, you've certainly made it clear to me.
All of us in Economy II have felt that the game is rigged, and have had to endure both "moral hazard" lectures from the Republicans and "flat world" lectures from many Democrats. We are being looted with the assistance of those in Economy I. The whole thing stinks.

What isn't mentioned is that many of those S&P 500 companies are American in name only. There are two economies. One is the world economy, where there are opportunities for investment that produce huge productivity increases in places like India and China. The other is the US economy, where the opportunities less and the returns lower.

Those that have access to the world economy, mostly money managers and a few large corporations, are thriving. They are taking the capital created in the United States and investing it in creating jobs overseas. In essence, as a country, we are being treated as a cash cow, milked for capital by world citizens whose economic fate is no longer connected to the success of the United States and the economic fate of other other Americans.

That is your two economies. One is the world economy. The other is the American economy. And most of us are trapped in the American economy with little ability to take advantage of opportunities to expand our business to China. We aren't exporting products, we are exporting financial capital, expertise, knowledge and jobs. We are being looted by the world citizens among us.
a wonderful selection of photographs and such nice light when and where  it is needed....depth and revelation in the images with an acknowledgment to the environment...well done Ozier Muhammad
What an amazing image. One in a million!

Good grief, I have seen this apologist argument before with almost the same sentences and still have the same problems with the facts and twisted economics presented in this version of the article.  First and foremost, we are exporting gasoline from those refineries down south because the rest of the world is willing to pay more than the piddly $4 price we pay in the US.  That southern leg will increase our gasoline exports, not reduce the price of gasoline in this country.  Second, Nebraska and TransCanada have worked out the details of the routing that will allow the XL pipeline to be built in its entirety and in addition to the southern leg, the northern leg is also under review.  See the TransCanada website for the "facts" the author conveniently overlooked.  At times, it is hard  for those of us who actually live and work in fly over country to remember how truly uniformed those that live on the coasts can be with their statements.
Superb    Good Stuff    Thanks, New Yorker depuis 1974.

Well done!  And add that the Canadian "oil" to be brought by the northern Keystone pipeline is actually from tar sands.  The energy required to boil that oil out of the earth makes tar sands far worse than other sources that Obama is opening up.  He made the right call (so far) in denying the northern Keystone pipeline.
"First, no President is able to significantly impact gas prices..."  Really? Then why did the Democrats universally pillory George Bush when gas prices skyrocketed in 2008?

Good comment, but the US is a net exporter of *refined* products.  We still import a whole lot more oil than we export, it's just that we import crude oil and export (significantly less) refined petroleum products, like gasoline.
Hasn't President Obama singlehandedly brought the price of natural gas to its lowest level in decades?
Yes, he's done a poor job of clearing the ruins of the post Bush-Cheney apocalyptic era, with the Replutocrats obstructing and sabotaging his every move.

Lets all HOPE that we can have four more years of Barack Obama.  That way we can have more continued unemployment, growing massive deficits, and numberless failed policies.  He's been so successful already, let's keep him!  I especially look forward to him spending us into oblivion.  Once we default and our children are faced with riots, poverty and the social instability that come with being  a developing third world nation, we can all look back and be so grateful to Barack Obama for his CHANGE.

The U.S. has much more power on the demand side than the supply side, as you imply, because we demand a lot more than we supply.  In addition, keystone will not increase world supply - it's just a bloody pipeline for production and refining that will take place anyway but that seems to keep getting lost.  Cutting our demand would lower the world oil price, but then we would have to have a motivator other than price at the pump to keep the demand low, and I'm not sure what that would be; those for whom environmental reasons are sufficient have likely already cut back their consumption as much as possible, so that can't be the motivator.

It's interesting that this article makes no mention of the fact that a president's policies can do little to affect the price of oil, especially on the supply side.  It certainly is a global commodity, the price of which is set by total worldwide supply and demand.  Yes, he is walking a tightrope when it comes to Keystone, but gas prices will not change significantly whether Keystone is built or not.

Schnur's word-smithery conceals that the Canadian oil would be delivered to a foreign free trade zone refinery at the Gulf, and every last drop exported after refining, with no taxes collected on the oil anywhere to help fund infrastructure or fund any clean-ups.

The southern portion of the pipeline from Cushing, Okla. to the Gulf refinery complex will alleviate the fact that every single barrel of oil that can be stuffed into storage in Cushing has been.

The pipeline is like a toll road built to the Gulf where no one pays tolls; where no one exits to eat or stay at a hotel or shop - indeed there are no exits.

The omissions and mis-representations in this piece make it more suited for distribution through the Faux Noise Machina propaganda outlets.

Gasoline prices have been kept artificially low through subsidies and tax loopholes for oil companies. Now the Republicans have decided that it is time to raise the prices for political reasons.

People are stupid if they believe that building the Keystone pipeline and risking pollution of our vital water resource will reduce the cost of gasoline within the USA. The crude oil carried by the Keystone pipeline to refineries in the Gulf will be refined and sold overseas, only to enrich oil companies. It will not bring down the cost of gasoline. It will contaminate our water and make the oil barons more wealthy.

Winning Progressive was way too nice to the person writing this article, DAN SCHNUR. I'm not going to waste my time setting the record strait, besides some of you would not believe me. So start banging around with online searches like oil pipelines in the US, (Transcanada completed the first pipe from the tar sands to Cushing long ago). Pipeline map, http://www.capp.ca/getdoc.aspx?DocID=191097 - Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers. A good map of US pipelines. Cushing Oklahoma tank farms, (they are all full and owners are building more) Transcanada.com, oilprice.com Embridge pipeline, embridge.com, Embrige pipeline system, ,, do a little research its good for you.

That the Times published this rot, basicaly a barely disguised political hit piece and has never bothered to inform the readers re the truth about oil. gas, pipelines or anything factual regarding the patrolium situation here or anywhere else is cause for serious questions about Times editorial policy. Or it is symptomatic of unjustifiable incompetence.

The Times did print Ian Urbina's reporting on Fracking but could not manage to tell the natural gas story. They let little bits out here and there but sidestepped the big story. One facet of it being the repeated claims of cheap natural gas for Americans. The only problem being that it is not cheap where we live, or where you live and pipelines are being planned and fought over to export in from the midwest through to the Oregon coast.

"Why don't we build cars that run on NG?"

For the same reasons we haven't been building or importing or marketing a lot of clean diesel or even small gasoline cars that use less petroleum, or more motor scooters, using bicycles, public transport, car-pooling, smarter growth, or drive more intelligently (e.g., coast to a stop light rather than gas it to a stop light, turn off the vehicle rather than idling). A large number of Americans don't want to change their behavior or even think about it, regardless of changing circumstances (population growth, countries developing, and economic recovery all push up oil prices). Amazing people in the U.S. still don't drive horse and buggies.

it's very simple conversion to make vehicles run on natural gas, I've had several but the prices and availability of the fuel can cause problems, there are a couple of other issues as well such as differences in combustion, but it's not difficult, nor is it expensive.

The change is in the tanks, lines, and delivery methods. And the pressure system.

I've also had generators which ran on natural gas. If you're near a source and it's cheap, then you might look for conversions. Fleet sales of natural gas was common and sometimes they can be picked up from government auctions, universities, and municipal surplus sales.

We have a glut of natural gas at the moment, and estimated reserves indicate we have a supply that could last for several hundred years.  Why don't we build cars that run on NG?  Honda used to make a Civic that ran on it, I believe.  Of course, the fracking process used to get all that gas may contaminate the water table.

Thank you, Stanton.
Cleared the whole mystery up with a stroke of your keyboard.
:-)

I have spent time there as well as up in the Bering sea, fortunately with modern surface radar and a ship with a welded steel hull, gas turbine engines with 80000 shaft horsepower and controllable reversible pitch screws. I can't imagine steaming at 21 knots with known ice with a steam ship incapable of reversing it's engines and taking all way off within 5 to 6 ship lengths. I can't imagine it was a simple task to engage a reverse turbine or reduction gear in an emergency situation.

The simple answer is that this was first and foremost the captains fault either through direct action or by the training of his officers. Going down with the ship does not release him from culpability.

The "race riots" were a pogrom. A mass killing and burning of a complete neighborhood of prospering black people in Tulsa.
In the aftermath a concealed clean up, also including terminology, since race riot implies two equal parties. Compare to Nazi lynchings being "race riots in Warsaw" or similar.
The world will die ignorant. Go ahead.

So killing someone for a specific goal makes it better?
Wow, good to know for their defense.
to Know Nothing:  Looks are everything.

Everyone got involved in Florida, first by emailing citizens, blogging, then by petition long before Sharpton or Jackson, because the police did not perform their duty in that case. That's the only reason anything is being done. Because millions of people were horrified and decided it would not be tolerated. I am proud and grateful to them all.

When the police do a fine job, as they have in Tulsa, no spectacle is required.
I agree.  No one yet knows what the motivations were so why would the speculations of unidentified "community leaders" be included in a NYTimes article?
Best remark of the day!  Thank you, sir.

Why is it when a white person kills a black person that then the white commentators like to all of a sudden voice their concern with black on black murder?

Have you been deeply concerned with black on black murder all this time? And now all of a sudden it seemed like the right time to bring it up? Is it coincidental that bringing up black on black crime takes the focus off the heinous crime perpetrated by the white people in this case?

Who even knows if the American Civil War happened? It was a really long time ago. I was born in Tulsa and grew up in Oklahoma City and only heard about the Tulsa riots in the last couple of decades. To say that they might not have happened is just ridiculous and cannot go unchallenged. You can be ignorant of history, but you cannot deny it to those of us who are not.

The NRA has 4 million members and is the largest citizen's lobby in the United States. It doesn't need any other source of income. A substantial percentage of its membership are police and security officers, present and former military and millions of sportsmen who attend and teach gun safety classes. One of the fastest growing category of NRA members and gun owners is women.

Through its state and local affiliates the NRA teaches firearms safety and marksmanship to thousands upon thousands of Americans every year. It carefully reviews firearms and publishes its findings in order to keep substandard firearms out of the marketplace. The NRA has a longstanding policy of helping legislators in drafting legislation to keep firearms out of the hands of criminals.

You really need to look into a subject before voicing uninformed opinions like this. Fortunately, most people will take your comments for what they are worth -- and that isn't much.
